text.0: dear ageless sacrificial drink is offered in lightdiscovering heavenpervading agni.
text.1: the gods spread forth through his celestial nature that he might bear the world up and sustain it.
text.2: the world was swallowed and concealed in darkness agni was born and light became apparent.
text.3: the deities the broad earth and the heavens and plants and waters gloried in his friendship.
text.4: inspired by gods who claim our adoration i now will laud eternal lofty agni.
text.5: him who hath spread abroad the earth with lustre this heaven and both the worlds and airs midregion.
text.6: earliest priest whom all the gods accepted and chose him and anointed him with butter.
text.7: he swiftly made all things that fly stand travel all that hath motion agni jātavedas.
text.8: because thou agni jātavedas stoodest at the worlds head with thy refulgent splendour.
text.9: we sent thee forth with hymns and songs and praises thou filledst heaven and earth god meet for worship.
text.10: head of the world is agni in the nighttime then as the sun at morn springs up and rises.
text.11: then to his task goes the prompt priest foreknowing the wondrous power of gods who must be honoured.
text.12: lovely is he who kindled in his greatness hath shone forth seated in the heavens refulgent.
text.13: with resonant hymns all gods who guard our bodies have offered up oblation in this agni.
text.14: first the gods brought the hymnal into being then they engendered agni then oblation.
text.15: he was their sacrifice that guards our bodies him the heavens know the earth the waters know him.
text.16: he agni whom the gods have generated in whom they offered up all worlds and creatures.
text.17: he with his bright glow heated earth and heaven urging himself right onward in his grandeur.
text.18: then by the laud the gods engendered agni in heaven who fills both worlds through strength and vigour.
text.19: they made him to appear in threefold essence he ripens plants of every form and nature.
text.20: what time the gods whose due is worship set him as sūrya son of aditi in heaven.
text.21: when the pair ever wandering sprang to being all creatures that existed looked upon them.
text.22: for all the world of life the gods made agni vaiśvānara to be the days bright banner.
text.23: him who hath spread abroad the radiant mornings and coming with his light unveils the darkness.
text.24: the wise and holy deities engendered agni vaiśvānara whom age neer touches.
text.25: the ancient star that wanders on for ever lofty and strong lord of the living being.
text.26: we call upon the sage with holy verses agni vaiśvānara the everbeaming.
text.27: who hath surpassed both heaven and earth in greatness he is a god below a god above us.
text.28: i have heard mention of two several pathways ways of the fathers and of gods and mortals.
text.29: on these two paths each moving creature travels each thing between the father and the mother.
text.30: these two united paths bear him who journeys born from the head and pondered with the spirit.
text.31: he stands directed to all things existing hasting unresting in his fiery splendour.
text.32: which of us twain knows where they speak together upper and lower of the two riteleaders.
text.33: our friends have helped to gather our assembly they came to sacrifice who will announce it.
text.34: how many are the fires and suns in number what is the number of the dawns and waters.
text.35: not jestingly i speak to you o fathers sages i ask you this for information.
text.36: as great as is the fairwinged mornings presence to him who dwells beside us mātariśvan.
text.37: is what the brahman does when he approaches to sacrifice and sits below the hotar.
